column2: XII. Darkness
column3: twelve. Darkness

column2: Sydney Carton paused in the street, not quite decided where to go.
column3: Sydney Carton paused in the street, not quite decided where to go.

column2: At Tellson's banking-house at nine, he said, with a musing face.
column3: At Tellson's banking house at nine, he said, with a musing face.

column2: Shall I do well, in the mean time, to show myself?	Shall I do well, in the mean time, to show myself?
I think so.
column3: I think so.

column2: But care, care, care! Let me think it out!"
column3: But care, care, care! Let me think it out!"

column2: Checking his steps which had begun to tend towards an object, he took a turn or two in the already darkening street, and traced the thought in his mind to its possible consequences.
column3: Checking his steps which had begun to tend towards an object, he took a turn or two in the already darkening street, and traced the thought in his mind to its possible consequences.

column2: His first impression was confirmed.
column3: His first impression was confirmed.

column2: Defarge had described himself, that day, as the keeper of a wine-shop in the Saint Antoine suburb.
column3: Defarge had described himself, that day, as the keeper of a wine shop in the Saint Antoine suburb.

column2: It was not difficult for one who knew the city well, to find his house without asking any question.
column3: It was not difficult for one who knew the city well, to find his house without asking any question.

column2: Having ascertained its situation, Carton came out of those closer streets again, and dined at a place of refreshment and fell sound asleep after dinner.
column3: Having ascertained its situation, Carton came out of those closer streets again, and dined at a place of refreshment and fell sound asleep after dinner.

column2: It was as late as seven o'clock when he awoke refreshed, and went out into the streets again.
column3: It was as late as seven o'clock when he awoke refreshed, and went out into the streets again.

column2: As he passed along towards Saint Antoine, he stopped at a shop-window where there was a mirror, and slightly altered the disordered arrangement of his loose cravat, and his coat-collar, and his wild hair.
column3: As he passed along towards Saint Antoine, he stopped at a shop window where there was a mirror, and slightly altered the disordered arrangement of his loose cravat, and his coat collar, and his wild hair.

column2: This done, he went on direct to Defarge's, and went in.
column3: This done, he went on direct to Defarge's, and went in.

column2: There happened to be no customer in the shop but Jacques Three, of the restless fingers and the croaking voice.
column3: There happened to be no customer in the shop but Jacques Three, of the restless fingers and the croaking voice.

column2: As Carton walked in, took his seat and asked (in very indifferent French) for a small measure of wine, Madame Defarge cast a careless glance at him, and then a keener, and then a keener, and then advanced to him herself, and asked him what it was he had ordered.
column3: As Carton walked in, took his seat and asked (in very indifferent French) for a small measure of wine, Madame Defarge cast a careless glance at him, and then a keener, and then a keener, and then advanced to him herself, and asked him what it was he had ordered.

column2: English? asked Madame Defarge, inquisitively raising her dark eyebrows.
column3: English? asked Madame Defarge, inquisitively raising her dark eyebrows.

column2: After looking at her, as if the sound of even a single French word were slow to express itself to him, he answered, in his former strong foreign accent.
column3: After looking at her, as if the sound of even a single French word were slow to express itself to him, he answered, in his former strong foreign accent.

column2: I am English!"
column3: I am English!"

column2: Madame Defarge returned to her counter to get the wine, and, as he took up a Jacobin journal and feigned to pore over it puzzling out its meaning, he heard her say, "I swear to you, like Evremonde!"
column3: Madame Defarge returned to her counter to get the wine, and, as he took up a Jacobin journal and feigned to pore over it puzzling out its meaning, he heard her say, "I swear to you, like Evremonde!"

column2: Defarge brought him the wine, and gave him Good Evening.
column3: Defarge brought him the wine, and gave him Good Evening.

column2: How?
column3: How?

column2: Good evening.
column3: Good evening.

column2: Oh!	Oh!
Good evening, citizen," filling his glass.
column3: Good evening, citizen," filling his glass.

column2: Ah! and good wine.	Ah! and good wine.
I drink to the Republic."
column3: I drink to the Republic."

column2: Why stop?	Why stop?
There is great force in that.
column3: There is great force in that.

column2: Well, well, reasoned Defarge, "but one must stop somewhere.
column3: Well, well, reasoned Defarge, "but one must stop somewhere.

column2: After all, the question is still where?"
column3: After all, the question is still where?"

column2: Magnificent! croaked Jacques Three.
column3: Magnificent! croaked Jacques Three.

column2: The Vengeance, also, highly approved.
column3: The Vengeance, also, highly approved.

column2: But this Doctor has suffered much; you have seen him to-day; you have observed his face when the paper was read."
column3: But this Doctor has suffered much; you have seen him to day; you have observed his face when the paper was read."

column2: I have observed his face to be not the face of a true friend of the Republic.
column3: I have observed his face to be not the face of a true friend of the Republic.

column2: Let him take care of his face!"
column3: Let him take care of his face!"

column2: I have observed her to-day, and I have observed her other days.
column3: I have observed her to day, and I have observed her other days.

column2: I have observed her in the court, and I have observed her in the street by the prison.
column3: I have observed her in the court, and I have observed her in the street by the prison.

column2: Let me but lift my finger--!" She seemed to raise it (the listener's eyes were always on his paper), and to let it fall with a rattle on the ledge before her, as if the axe had dropped.
column3: Let me but lift my finger-!" She seemed to raise it (the listener's eyes were always on his paper), and to let it fall with a rattle on the ledge before her, as if the axe had dropped.

column2: She is an Angel! said The Vengeance, and embraced her.
column3: She is an Angel! said The Vengeance, and embraced her.

column2: Not if to lift this glass would do it!	Not if to lift this glass would do it!
I say, stop there."
column3: I say, stop there."

column2: Listen!
column3: Listen!

column2: Ask my husband, is that so."
column3: Ask my husband, is that so."

column2: In the beginning of the great days, when the Bastille falls, he finds this paper of to-day, and he brings it home, and in the middle of the night when this place is clear and shut, we read it, here on this spot, by the light of this lamp.	In the beginning of the great days, when the Bastille falls, he finds this paper of to day, and he brings it home, and in the middle of the night when this place is clear and shut, we read it, here on this spot, by the light of this lamp.

That night, I tell him, when the paper is read through, and the lamp is burnt out, and the day is gleaming in above those shutters and between those iron bars, that I have now a secret to communicate.	That night, I tell him, when the paper is read through, and the lamp is burnt out, and the day is gleaming in above those shutters and between those iron bars, that I have now a secret to communicate.
Ask him, is that so."
column3: Ask him, is that so."

column2: I communicate to him that secret.	I communicate to him that secret.
It is so, assented Defarge once more.
column3: It is so, assented Defarge once more.

column2: Then tell Wind and Fire where to stop, returned madame; "but don't tell me."
column3: Then tell Wind and Fire where to stop, returned madame; "but don't tell me."

column2: Both her hearers derived a horrible enjoyment from the deadly nature of her wrath--the listener could feel how white she was, without seeing her--and both highly commended it.
column3: Both her hearers derived a horrible enjoyment from the deadly nature of her wrath-the listener could feel how white she was, without seeing her-and both highly commended it.

column2: Defarge, a weak minority, interposed a few words for the memory of the compassionate wife of the Marquis; but only elicited from his own wife a repetition of her last reply.
column3: Defarge, a weak minority, interposed a few words for the memory of the compassionate wife of the Marquis; but only elicited from his own wife a repetition of her last reply.

column2: Tell the Wind and the Fire where to stop; not me!
column3: Tell the Wind and the Fire where to stop; not me!

column2: The English customer paid for what he had had, perplexedly counted his change, and asked, as a stranger, to be directed towards the National Palace.
column3: The English customer paid for what he had had, perplexedly counted his change, and asked, as a stranger, to be directed towards the National Palace.

column2: Madame Defarge took him to the door, and put her arm on his, in pointing out the road. The English customer was not without his reflections then, that it might be a good deed to seize that arm, lift it, and strike under it sharp and deep.
column3: Madame Defarge took him to the door, and put her arm on his, in pointing out the road. The English customer was not without his reflections then, that it might be a good deed to seize that arm, lift it, and strike under it sharp and deep.

column2: But, he went his way, and was soon swallowed up in the shadow of the prison wall.
column3: But, he went his way, and was soon swallowed up in the shadow of the prison wall.

column2: He said he had been with Lucie until just now, and had only left her for a few minutes, to come and keep his appointment.
column3: He said he had been with Lucie until just now, and had only left her for a few minutes, to come and keep his appointment.

column2: Her father had not been seen, since he quitted the banking-house towards four o'clock.
column3: Her father had not been seen, since he quitted the banking house towards four o'clock.

column2: He had been more than five hours gone: where could he be?
column3: He had been more than five hours gone: where could he be?

column2: He waited and waited, and the clock struck twelve; but Doctor Manette did not come back.
column3: He waited and waited, and the clock struck twelve; but Doctor Manette did not come back.

column2: Where could he be?
column3: Where could he be?

column2: The instant he entered the room, it was plain that all was lost.
column3: The instant he entered the room, it was plain that all was lost.

column2: As he stood staring at them, they asked him no question, for his face told them everything.
column3: As he stood staring at them, they asked him no question, for his face told them everything.

column2: I cannot find it, said he, "and I must have it.
column3: I cannot find it, said he, "and I must have it.

column2: Where is it?"
column3: Where is it?"

column2: I have been looking everywhere for my bench, and I can't find it.
column3: I have been looking everywhere for my bench, and I can't find it.

column2: What have they done with my work?
column3: What have they done with my work?

column2: They looked at one another, and their hearts died within them.
column3: They looked at one another, and their hearts died within them.

column2: Receiving no answer, he tore his hair, and beat his feet upon the ground, like a distracted child.
column3: Receiving no answer, he tore his hair, and beat his feet upon the ground, like a distracted child.

column2: Don't torture a poor forlorn wretch, he implored them, with a dreadful cry; "but give me my work!
column3: Don't torture a poor forlorn wretch, he implored them, with a dreadful cry; "but give me my work!

column2: It was so clearly beyond hope to reason with him, or try to restore him, that--as if by agreement--they each put a hand upon his shoulder, and soothed him to sit down before the fire, with a promise that he should have his work presently.
column3: It was so clearly beyond hope to reason with him, or try to restore him, that-as if by agreement-they each put a hand upon his shoulder, and soothed him to sit down before the fire, with a promise that he should have his work presently.

column2: He sank into the chair, and brooded over the embers, and shed tears.
column3: He sank into the chair, and brooded over the embers, and shed tears.

column2: As if all that had happened since the garret time were a momentary fancy, or a dream, Mr. Lorry saw him shrink into the exact figure that Defarge had had in keeping.
column3: As if all that had happened since the garret time were a momentary fancy, or a dream, mr Lorry saw him shrink into the exact figure that Defarge had had in keeping.

column2: Affected, and impressed with terror as they both were, by this spectacle of ruin, it was not a time to yield to such emotions.
column3: Affected, and impressed with terror as they both were, by this spectacle of ruin, it was not a time to yield to such emotions.

column2: His lonely daughter, bereft of her final hope and reliance, appealed to them both too strongly.
column3: His lonely daughter, bereft of her final hope and reliance, appealed to them both too strongly.

column2: Again, as if by agreement, they looked at one another with one meaning in their faces.
column3: Again, as if by agreement, they looked at one another with one meaning in their faces.

column2: Carton was the first to speak:
column3: Carton was the first to speak:

column2: The last chance is gone: it was not much.	The last chance is gone: it was not much.
Yes; he had better be taken to her.
column3: Yes; he had better be taken to her.

column2: But, before you go, will you, for a moment, steadily attend to me?
column3: But, before you go, will you, for a moment, steadily attend to me?

column2: I do not doubt it, answered Mr. Lorry.
column3: I do not doubt it, answered mr Lorry.

column2: Say on.
column3: Say on.

column2: Carton stooped to pick up the coat, which lay almost entangling his feet.
column3: Carton stooped to pick up the coat, which lay almost entangling his feet.

column2: Carton took it up, and there was a folded paper in it.
column3: Carton took it up, and there was a folded paper in it.

column2: We should look at this! he said.
column3: We should look at this! he said.

column2: Mr. Lorry nodded his consent.
column3: mr Lorry nodded his consent.

column2: What is it? asked Mr. Lorry, eagerly.
column3: What is it? asked mr Lorry, eagerly.

column2: A moment!	A moment!
Let me speak of it in its place.
column3: Let me speak of it in its place.

column2: First," he put his hand in his coat, and took another paper from it, "that is the certificate which enables me to pass out of this city.
column3: First," he put his hand in his coat, and took another paper from it, "that is the certificate which enables me to pass out of this city.

column2: Look at it.
column3: Look at it.

column2: You see--Sydney Carton, an Englishman?"
column3: You see-Sydney Carton, an Englishman?"

column2: Mr. Lorry held it open in his hand, gazing in his earnest face.
column3: mr Lorry held it open in his hand, gazing in his earnest face.

column2: Keep it for me until to-morrow.	Keep it for me until to morrow.
Why not?
column3: Why not?

column2: I don't know; I prefer not to do so.	I don't know; I prefer not to do so.
Now, take this paper that Doctor Manette has carried about him.
column3: Now, take this paper that Doctor Manette has carried about him.

column2: It is a similar certificate, enabling him and his daughter and her child, at any time, to pass the barrier and the frontier!
column3: It is a similar certificate, enabling him and his daughter and her child, at any time, to pass the barrier and the frontier!

column2: You see?"
column3: You see?"

column2: Yes!
column3: Yes!

column2: Perhaps he obtained it as his last and utmost precaution against evil, yesterday.	Perhaps he obtained it as his last and utmost precaution against evil, yesterday.
When is it dated?
column3: When is it dated?

column2: But no matter; don't stay to look; put it up carefully with mine and your own.
column3: But no matter; don't stay to look; put it up carefully with mine and your own.

column2: It is good, until recalled.
column3: It is good, until recalled.

column2: They are in great danger.	They are in great danger.
I know it from her own lips.
column3: I know it from her own lips.

column2: I have overheard words of that woman's, to-night, which have presented their danger to me in strong colours.
column3: I have overheard words of that woman's, to night, which have presented their danger to me in strong colours.

column2: He confirms me.
column3: He confirms me.

column2: Don't look so horrified.
column3: Don't look so horrified.

column2: Heaven grant I may, Carton!	Heaven grant I may, Carton!
But how?"
column3: But how?"

column2: You know it is a capital crime, to mourn for, or sympathise with, a victim of the Guillotine.
column3: You know it is a capital crime, to mourn for, or sympathise with, a victim of the Guillotine.

column2: She and her father would unquestionably be guilty of this crime, and this woman (the inveteracy of whose pursuit cannot be described) would wait to add that strength to her case, and make herself doubly sure.
column3: She and her father would unquestionably be guilty of this crime, and this woman (the inveteracy of whose pursuit cannot be described) would wait to add that strength to her case, and make herself doubly sure.

column2: You follow me?"
column3: You follow me?"

column2: Your preparations have been completed for some days, to return to England.
column3: Your preparations have been completed for some days, to return to England.

column2: Early to-morrow have your horses ready, so that they may be in starting trim at two o'clock in the afternoon."
column3: Early to morrow have your horses ready, so that they may be in starting trim at two o'clock in the afternoon."

column2: It shall be done!
column3: It shall be done!

column2: His manner was so fervent and inspiring, that Mr. Lorry caught the flame, and was as quick as youth.
column3: His manner was so fervent and inspiring, that mr Lorry caught the flame, and was as quick as youth.

column2: You are a noble heart.	You are a noble heart.

For the sake of her child and her father, press upon her the necessity of leaving Paris, with them and you, at that hour.	For the sake of her child and her father, press upon her the necessity of leaving Paris, with them and you, at that hour.
Tell her that it was her husband's last arrangement.
column3: Tell her that it was her husband's last arrangement.

column2: I thought so.	I thought so.
Quietly and steadily have all these arrangements made in the courtyard here, even to the taking of your own seat in the carriage. The moment I come to you, take me in, and drive away."
column3: Quietly and steadily have all these arrangements made in the courtyard here, even to the taking of your own seat in the carriage. The moment I come to you, take me in, and drive away."

column2: I understand that I wait for you under all circumstances?
column3: I understand that I wait for you under all circumstances?

column2: You have my certificate in your hand with the rest, you know, and will reserve my place.	You have my certificate in your hand with the rest, you know, and will reserve my place.
Wait for nothing but to have my place occupied, and then for England!"
column3: Wait for nothing but to have my place occupied, and then for England!"

column2: Why, then, said Mr. Lorry, grasping his eager but so firm and steady hand, "it does not all depend on one old man, but I shall have a young and ardent man at my side."
column3: Why, then, said mr Lorry, grasping his eager but so firm and steady hand, "it does not all depend on one old man, but I shall have a young and ardent man at my side."

column2: Promise me solemnly that nothing will influence you to alter the course on which we now stand pledged to one another."
column3: Promise me solemnly that nothing will influence you to alter the course on which we now stand pledged to one another."

column2: Nothing, Carton.
column3: Nothing, Carton.

column2: I hope to do my part faithfully."
column3: I hope to do my part faithfully."

column2: And I hope to do mine.	And I hope to do mine.
Now, good bye!"
column3: Now, good bye!"

column2: Though he said it with a grave smile of earnestness, and though he even put the old man's hand to his lips, he did not part from him then.
column3: Though he said it with a grave smile of earnestness, and though he even put the old man's hand to his lips, he did not part from him then.

column2: He helped him so far to arouse the rocking figure before the dying embers, as to get a cloak and hat put upon it, and to tempt it forth to find where the bench and work were hidden that it still moaningly besought to have.
column3: He helped him so far to arouse the rocking figure before the dying embers, as to get a cloak and hat put upon it, and to tempt it forth to find where the bench and work were hidden that it still moaningly besought to have.

column2: He walked on the other side of it and protected it to the courtyard of the house where the afflicted heart--so happy in the memorable time when he had revealed his own desolate heart to it--outwatched the awful night.
column3: He walked on the other side of it and protected it to the courtyard of the house where the afflicted heart-so happy in the memorable time when he had revealed his own desolate heart to it-outwatched the awful night.

column2: He entered the courtyard and remained there for a few moments alone, looking up at the light in the window of her room.
